items.title: After Rocket Attack, an Israeli City Seems Resigned to More in the Future
items.abstract: Intense fighting with Gaza has heightened concerns about safety in Rishon LeZion and seems to have renewed the sentiment among residents of the unlikeliness of a long-term solution in their lifetimes.

items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
items.abstract: Even amid other environmental gains, it is the improvement in air quality that has most burnished the city’s green credentials.

items.title: Review: Bank on the Seafood at Fish Urban Dining in Ridgewood
items.abstract: Situated in a former Bank of America branch on East Ridgewood Avenue, the seafood restaurant has 30-foot ceilings, huge chandeliers and extends into what was the vault.

items.title: Bitter Debate Over Nuclear Power Simmers in Rural South Korea
items.abstract: In 2010, three villages agreed to give up their land to make room for a power plant, plunging the area into a battle over whether the plant would be a savior or a death knell.

items.title: Intimate, Haunting Portraits of New York City Youth
items.abstract: The photographer (and model) Ethan James Green finds many of the subjects in his ongoing series of creatives on social media.

items.title: Recipes for Bright Lights, Big Cities
items.abstract: So many options for dinner tonight: pasta with broccoli and anchovy sauce, miso chicken, kimchi soup and more.

items.title: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
items.abstract: Sustainable housing plans have transformed Hammarby Sjostad, a neighborhood in Stockholm. Now, new cultural projects are providing another boost.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: They Married at City Hall (But Didn’t Toss the Bouquet)
items.abstract: Three couples share their stories after marrying on a December day at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, where the brides also rented their flowers.

items.title: Washington’s Strong Economy, Financed by Taxpayers, Takes Hit From Shutdown
items.abstract: As the country nears the end of its third week of a government shutdown, the nation’s capital has borne the brunt of its consequences.

items.title: To Save East River Park, the City Intends to Bury It
items.abstract: A plan to protect the Lower East Side from flooding was just rejected by the city, replaced with a drastic revision that costs twice as much but does not disrupt traffic.

items.title: Noncitizens’ Right to Vote Becomes Law in New York City
items.abstract: Starting next year, 800,000 legal permanent residents will be eligible to vote in municipal elections.
keywords: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)

items.title: Breakouts and lockdowns in Chinese cities make a risk-free Olympics look unlikely.
items.abstract: Officials are racing to extinguish a spate of coronavirus infections around the country.

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
items.abstract: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
keywords: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

items.title: A Mayor and the Challenge of Making the City Safer
items.abstract: Eric Adams made public safety a campaign issue. Now, as mayor, he will be held accountable.
